intro: Acacia irrorata subsp. irrorata, commonly known as the white wattle, is a shrub or small tree native to arid and semi-arid regions of Australia. It is characterized by its slender, often multi-branched stems and bipinnate leaves that are finely divided. The plant produces yellow flowers in globular or cylindrical spikes, which are typically arranged in clusters at the ends of branches. It is well adapted to drought conditions, with a deep root system that allows it to survive in nutrient-poor soils. The species is also valued for its role in stabilizing soils and providing habitat for native wildlife.

This subspecies is commonly found in arid and semi-arid regions across these Australian states. It typically grows in open woodlands, shrublands, and along rocky outcrops. The plant is well adapted to dry conditions and can thrive in sandy or gravelly soils. Its distribution reflects its ability to survive in harsh, inland environments of southeastern Australia.
